title: Political and Social Theory Lexicon
description: Specialized vocabulary for political philosophy and social critique

items.definition: Dominance of one group over others, especially through cultural or ideological means
items.example: Gramsci analyzed how cultural hegemony operates through consent rather than coercion.

items.definition: The treatment of abstract concepts as if they were concrete things; making something abstract seem real
items.example: Lukács critiqued the reification of human relations under capitalism.

items.definition: The process of putting theoretical knowledge into practice; practical application of ideas
items.example: For Marx, philosophy must be united with revolutionary praxis.

items.definition: Of lower rank; in postcolonial theory, groups marginalized and excluded from power
items.example: Spivak famously asked whether the subaltern can speak.

items.definition: The process by which ideology addresses individuals and constitutes them as subjects
items.example: Althusser's theory of interpellation explains how individuals become subjects of ideology.

items.definition: The governance of populations through administration of biological life processes
items.example: Foucault analyzed how biopolitics emerged in the modern era to manage populations.

items.definition: A copy without an original; an image that has replaced or superseded reality
items.example: Baudrillard argued that contemporary society is characterized by simulacra.

items.definition: The weakening of ties between culture and place; the severing of social relations from local contexts
items.example: Deleuze and Guattari describe capitalism as a deterritorializing force.
